channel.title: Just In Time?
channel.description:
Recently, I've heard some talk about the Just In Time compiler (or compilation rather). Supposedly it performs bytecode optimization that re-orders the oder of execution by the virtual machine and keeps a cache of machine code of commonly called code. If I've misunderstood this, please correct me.
Any who, it was claimed in the conversation that the use of said compilation method creates similar benchmarks in Java applications comparable to C; obviously, just hearing about this subject I am not very familiar with the technicalities/efficiency and I am pretty skeptical. I am asking if this is true/some-what true (it's obviously that something of this nature would aid speeding up bytecode execution, but to what extent)?

item.title: Just In Time?

item.description:
@lawl wrote:

super_:

Open-source since inception, supports Ahead-of-Time compilation, uses GCC front-end, GPL license

we need to go deeper !

item.title: Just In Time?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Sun’s VM is known as HotSpot… it supports dynamic run-time compilation (commonly known as Just-In-Time compilation)

Read full topic

item.title: Just In Time?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

VTEC KICKIN IN YO

Read full topic

item.title: Just In Time?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:397386”]I’m pretty sure Sun Java ditched the hotspot compiler years ago, and now their compiler is based on JIT, so you already use a Just In Time compiler most likely.

And yes, it has the ability, at least in theory, to make code that is actually faster that C or C++ because it can optimize on the fly, and pre-compiled languages can only optimize based on what in knows during compile time. I’ve never actually ran benchmarks on this, but I know they are plenty close enough now performance-wise to not matter at all in a desktop application.[/quote]

That’s pretty impressive; especially since Java has been notoriously known as a slower language.

Read full topic

item.title: Just In Time?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I’m pretty sure Sun Java ditched the hotspot compiler years ago, and now their compiler is based on JIT, so you already use a Just In Time compiler most likely.

And yes, it has the ability, at least in theory, to make code that is actually faster that C or C++ because it can optimize on the fly, and pre-compiled languages can only optimize based on what in knows during compile time. I’ve never actually ran benchmarks on this, but I know they are plenty close enough now performance-wise to not matter at all in a desktop application.

Read full topic

item.title: Just In Time?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

I thought Java’s was that Hotspot thing and C# has the JIT. I’m really stoned, so sorry if incorrect.
